title: What are some rap songs everyone should listen to? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve been waiting years to answer this question. Here’s the first song. As far as I’m concerned this is the most perfect rap song I’ve ever heard, and I’m a fan. Don’t fast forward, each verse builds on the other.  Fat Cats Bigga Fish Let’s set aside the funky music which is great. The first two verses start as a perfect gangster/hustler rap song. But not on a stolen Bentley, all about the Benjamins level. Two highlights: Rapping about what a great criminal he is: “I’m a hustler for real, so y’know I got the stolen bus pass.”Talking about the wallet he just stole: “Damn this motherfucka had hella Andrew Jacksons!”If every rap song was strictly these two verses I’d be satisfied. Punchlines. Similes. Voice control. Attitude. I love this song so much I try to downplay it in fear that I’m over selling it. But then he flips the third verse and it’s lyrical and true and insane. Mr Coke said to Mr Mayor: "you know, we got a process like Ice T's hairWe put up the funds for your election campaignAnd, oh, um, waiter can you bring the champagne?Our real estate firm says opportunity's arousingTo make some condos out of low-income housingImmediately, we need some media heatTo say that gangs run the street and then we bring in the police fleet!Harass and beat everybody til they look inebriatedWhen we buy the land, motherfuckas will appreciate itDon't worry about the Urban League or Jesse JacksonMy man that owns Marlboro donated a fat sum"And he just told a poem in first person about gentrification in rhyme. He built up the biggest player in the hood to explain to you that it is absolutely nothing compared to the real moral crimes that occur over Cuban cigars and champagne. It doesn’t matter what corners you cut or stakes you pull, the game is rigged. Here’s the conversation of the people who rig it, in perfect syncopation. Did I mention I love this song? Every time that third verse pulls the rug out from under me. Cigarettes, the police force, the Urban League, the mayor, gentrification, they all work together, they all feed on each other. And you think you’re a player because you’re out here hustling hamburgers. Again, if every rap song was this song I’d be okay with it. But there’s a second song by Boots Riley that you need to hear as well.  Me and Jesus the Pimp in a ’79 Granada Last Night Here’s how you know Boots knows exactly what he’s talking about. The last couplet of the first verse, “Ain't gonna mash too fast, cause my tags ain't right, Me and Jesus the Pimp in a '79 Granada last night”. If you truly are poor, your tax/safety is never updated. And you know any out of line driving, with bad tags it is not only an automatic ticket, but it is also automatic reasonable suspicion, a cop cannot get in trouble for pulling you over, once he sees you have bad tags. This is from experience right here, I’m going to drive as legal as possible, because I know he can pull me over anyway, and I don’t want to draw attention, because then who knows what he’ll find in the car. I have one quibble with this song, he makes the moral explicit when he didn’t need to. I think it is so obvious, making it explicit sort of shows distrust in the audience’s ability to understand the message. I’ve worked through it. This poetry is insane, the word paintings and the storytelling. Please listen to these songs. I really like them and like to share them with people looking for good hip hop. I also think everyone should listen to Po Pimp, by Do or Die. but I think people have heard that one. Boots is someone I think more people need to hear.

OMG THERE ARE SO MANY: Callin’ My Name by The Jacka & Mistah Fab  Mac Hand by The Jacka  Gettin’ It by Too Short  Git Up, Git Out by Outlast  Passin’ Me By by Pharcyde  Deja Vu by J Cole  Feeling Myself by Mac Dre  Neighbors by J Cole  Love Yourz by J Cole  Lit by Bas  Love Souvenir by Bas  Man On The Moon by Kid Cudi  First Of The Month, Crossroads, and Thuggish Ruggish Bone by Bone Thugs & Harmony    Just What I Am by Kid Cudi & King Chip  And everything by Tupac Shakur. Everything.
